How about add a 'Tested:' section with the output of a busctl introspect?
That sounds like a great idea. I'll aim to include this in the next draft.

I think the CI tools don't like the width of the formatted introspect lines in the commit messages. 

I *think* that might be why the latest commit validation failed (that, plus this version relies on a phosphor-dbus-interface YAML that's only a gerrit page for now).

Any suggestions?

Yea, looks like that is why it failed.  It even suggested a fix, in this case the triple quotes:

-: UC1 Line exceeds max length (90>72).
    It's possible you intended to use one of the following exceptions:
    1. Put logs or shell script in a quoted section with triple quotes (''')
        before and after the section
    2. Put a long link at the bottom in a footnote.
        example: [1] https://my_long_link.com

Looking over the console output again, I must not have skimmed far up enough above the "commit_gitlint: FAILED" line to see it - thanks for pointing it out! 

I'll keep that in mind, and will fix this next update (also working on some interface tweaks based on discussions with phosphor-dbus-interface maintainer)
Thanks for looking this stuff over and offering suggestions, folks!
Currently traveling across Asia, will be back to focusing on this probably the last week on June. Thanks again for the help looking over this stuff, folks!
Can you still submit the D-Bus yaml for this interface in phosphor-dbus-interfaces?  that way it's documented.
Can do, especially since it seems like the 'MachineContext' interface name is going over better than previous suggestions did.
YAML has been submitted @ https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/73260

Why? This isn't a library, is it?

Perhaps we can address this anti-pattern as part of the cleanups: [Placing internal headers in a parallel subtree](https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/anti-patterns.md#placing-internal-headers-in-a-parallel-subtree)

Thanks for the link to explain the issue! 

I believe the usage of the /include directory was part of the original phosphor-u-boot-env-mgr structure, and it hadn't occurred to me to change it.

I'll remove the /include directory in the next revision.
Done
Why something different from the service name?

You're asking why I specified BusName=xyz.openbmc_project.MachineContext in the servicefile instead of something like phosphor-u-boot-env-devtree-nodesd, right?

In the case of the pre-existing phosphor-u-boot-env-mgr daemon, the daemon has functions accessible through the d-bus interface, so it has its own bus on d-bus.

The new devtree-nodesd daemon has no user-callable functions - it just reads nodes then writes data to the MachineContext interface, so it doesn't have its 'own' bus on d-bus. That was my reasoning, at least.

I specified MachineContext for BusName in the service file here because that lets it use the appearance of the MachineContext bus to signal that the service has successfully done what it needs to do (otherwise it'll think the d-bus service failed to start, timeout, then remove the MachineContext bus and any included data a shortly after boot).

> You're asking why I specified BusName=xyz.openbmc_project.MachineContext in the servicefile instead of something like phosphor-u-boot-env-devtree-nodesd, right?

Usually the BusName == the name of the service file, so this file would be named xyz.openbmc_project.MachineContext.service.
Done

Given this is fairly isolated, it would be good to see this implemented with the sdbusplus async APIs rather than the ASIO APIs.

I've added Patrick to Reviewers to provide some feedback here.

That isn't something I had considered, but Ian Woloschin (just added as a reviewer) was in agreement when I discussed this Gerrit review with him.

I'll go ahead and start looking into doing this for the next draft.

Quick note (Chris Sides, different account here): I was hoping to have this worked out the other week before going out the door, but didn't manage to finish before heading a month long trip across Asia.

I didn't bring authenticators for my work accounts with me, hence the alternative github account...

Anyways, thanks again for the advice everyone, and I'll be back to working on this once I'm back in the US towards the end of June.
Done
This build now relies on (currently gerrit-only) interfaces defined in YAML @ https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/73260

if this is read only ROM then only one of these should be supplied, the factory assigned one not the locally assignable in use one.   I always forget which is which.


or did I misunderstand and this is the MAC assigned to the server (host) and not the management controller (BMC)?

No, you're correct. It's my understanding the 'local-mac-address' field is the first thing populated, and then the 'mac-address' node is populated only if a differing MAC is assigned after the initial one.

https://devicetree-specification.readthedocs.io/en/v0.3/device-bindings.html#network-devices

Originally, I was planning to list both, but the next versions of the daemon will only have one (partially to better fit with the NetworkInterface dbus interface we're partially relying on now).

why are these writable?    because the pdi binding says so?    what happens when a write is attempted?   crash?  ignore?   error?

add to testing.

>because the pdi binding says so?

You are correct here. These properties were created via sdbusplus bindings being generated, and I had not considered the "what happens if you try to write to them" aspect.

I'll look into this, thanks for calling it!

Switched from using custom-defined DBus interface 'MachineContext' to instead using existing interfaces 'Inventory.Item.NetworkInterface' for MAC address and 'Inventory.Decorator.Asset" for model & serial number.

Based on discussion @ https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/73260/comment/e0226ae4_d7e514dd/

I don't really have a problem with the concept of grabbing information from the kernel and putting it on dbus, but this does not have anything to do with u-boot-env-mgr. It seems like this new service should be in its own repo or in entity manager itself. Not sure where it should land, but not here. Maybe similar to openpower-vpd-parser, there should be an hpe-vpd-parser repo.

IIRC Ed Tanous originally (pretty strongly) pushed for leveraging phosphor-u-boot-env-mgr on the basis that anything coming from device-tree is being passed in from u-boot from OBMC's perspective. 

I'd be okay with putting up an entirely new repo if that's where folks think we should go, but seems like there might be some community discussion to be had on the topic. 

I'll ping Ed on Discord to this thread and see where that takes things.
whoops- didn't mean to mark this as 'resolved'

> on the basis that anything coming from device-tree is being passed in from u-boot from OBMC's perspective.

first Uboot is just plumbing this is not touching the environment.   most of the device tree comes from the kernel source tree.   Should the initrd and kernel binary also be considered as coming from Uboot?

While we could have chosen to place these attributes in the Uboot environment variables the review feedback was to use standard DTS properties spread across the existing nodes according to standard bindings with extension only when needed.

Second exposeing DTS properties which need to be interpreted as strings, byte arrays, and others raw binary data, is quite different from the Uboot environment which has a collection of name value pairs and are always strings.


This should be a new binary with it's own configuration file.   how it's hosted in which repository I'll defer.   (reads code)  Oh it is a separate binary but with a silly meaningless name.


I have not yet reviewed the code especially for being general purpose.  (read code) 
ok it's not general purpose and I made several other comments.

>first Uboot is just plumbing this is not touching the environment

I believe I understand your point.

A bit of background 'point of interest' here is that HPE's current methodology is to have HW identifying VPD read from a secure element during boot, then an HPE-specific version of u-boot modifies the flat device tree to add in the discovered information -- and that's how it's made available to OBMC in HPE's case.

That said, there's no requirement for how that data is made available to the device tree for other platforms, and HPE's methodology may change again in the future (but probably won't anytime too soon).

>Second exposeing DTS properties which need to be interpreted as strings, byte arrays, and others raw binary data, is quite different from the Uboot environment which has a collection of name value pairs and are always strings

I'll keep this in mind. I actually need to update the 'tested' part of the commit, now that I look again. The latest commit of the code only creates one 'MAC' field instead of two now, and it's presented as a string displaying the hex values.

>it is a separate binary but with a silly meaningless name

I'll consider some potentially more meaningful names for this daemon. Thanks a ton for all the input - some of it I'll need to return and reply to later.

I'll put together some updated code with an updated 'testing' section - plus I've got a few more comments to come back and reply to later.

Thank you so much for taking the time to look over this stuff and offer suggestions, folks!

this is just meaningless addition of names.

drop u-boot-env it's meaningless and only specifies the repository not any function.

My reasoning here was that there was already a 'u-boot-env' daemon in this repo (even if no one was referring this repo due to lack of existing recipes), and I wanted to make it simple to decide which one(s) to have active if someone pulls this subproject into their build.

Based on recent commentary from folks other than Ed Tanous (so far), it seems like we're moving towards maybe *not* hosting this daemon in this particular repo afterall...
see above, rename.
please add trailing new lines to source text files.
Will do.
from this description I thought it was serving both but it has an independent main.

no subdirectories ?

the MAC address should be in the Ethernet device node not the machine top level.

Seems like you would need to check compatible property to know which node to find.  that is a file with a series of NUL terminated strings.

I was going to suggest looking at compatible to find the right node but realized a better solution is to define an alias and extract the device mode path from the string with NUL terminator under |/aliases/soc-ethernet` or whatever you choose (I'd be ok with whatever DTS naming for the first Ethernet interface).

All the nodes we care about for now are at the device-tree root node level.

There's effectively a hardcoded list of paths to supported nodes, with the idea that it could be possible to pull data from deeper paths in the future if the community wants to.

Hmmm I am not used to seeing cast near std:: pair usage.

is this a cast only to confirm the type?
Correct. The cast is not required - I added it hoping it would make what's being done more clear to anyone reading the code.
So we rely on std::getline to trim the NUL and only expect one string?
same (getline)
my understanding is to call format directly and not use stream operators.
see avtif for host, but why is MAC address on the something to populate the chassis and not the BMC Ethernet?

>see avtif for host

Can you clarify what this means?

>why is MAC address on the something to populate the chassis

The 'MAC-Address' and 'Local-MAC-Address' fields were both originally included due community discussions as 'low hanging fruit' since this data about the system OBMC is booting on can be obtained through root nodes in device-tree

https://devicetree-specification.readthedocs.io/en/v0.3/device-bindings.html#network-devices

no subdirectories 

the MAC address should be in the Ethernet device node not the machine top level.

I expect the DTS checker to complain about unknown binding for the properties.   except it's not in the version it sees.

seems like you would need to check compatible property to know which node to find.  that is a file with a series of NUL terminated strings.

or just hardcode the path since it's inside the soc, and would take configuration for the object to decorate.

better would be to define an alias and read the device path from `/aliases/soc-etgernet`, trim the NUL from the string and open that relative path directory, optionally check compatible, then open the MAC address file.
I

this file represents C thinking of a single header to configure the logic and define the parameters instead of C++ of defining a header to implement a class.

the supported paths and naming with a trailing d for daemon 
represent this.   place them in another file or move to the cpp.

After getting pushback re: adding custom interface "xyz.openbmc_project.MachineContext," I have switched to leveraging already-existing interfaces inventory.decorator.asset and inventory.item.networkinterface (using server_t to wrap the inheritances).

This service still intends to use path
"xyz.openbmc_project.MachineContext"

Please use this space for further discussions of dbus interface or path usages
correction: path xyz/openbmc_project/MachineContext
does this belong to the same object or is it just to avoid defining a second object path?

It's all intended to describe the same physical object overall - it's all supposed to be data giving context for the board OBMC is running on ('model id' is the data HPE needs to key off. The rest is just added as 'low hanging fruit' for a device-tree -> dbus daemon based on previous community discussions)
